summary: The document details the payroll and employment specifics of John J. Farmer, Jr., a summer intern with the Select Committee on Assassinations (HSCA), under the Assassination Records Review Board. It outlines the administrative oversight leading to his overpayment, the subsequent adjustments, and the bureaucratic communications regarding his employment termination and salary repayment. The records include payroll authorizations, memoranda on employment terms, and the process of addressing the overpayment, with personal information like Social Security numbers redacted for privacy.
key_findings: John J. Farmer, Jr. was overpaid due to an administrative oversight when his termination was not promptly communicated to the Budget Office.
The overpayment covered the period August 20-31, 1977, initially amounting to $220.00, later adjusted to $199.38 after withholdings.
Farmer's role transitioned from a part-time intern at a monthly salary of $300.00 to a full-time position with a base annual salary of $7,200.00.
The document sheds light on the HSCA's internal bureaucratic processes and communications concerning payroll and employment adjustments.
Personal privacy was protected through the redaction of Social Security numbers, with a review date set for 2017.
